This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.From: Wufoo
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: Submitted Public Comment Form
Date: Thursday, August 21, 2025 9:17:35 PM
Name * Michaela  Carlson
Provide the docket's number. 24-198
Leave a comment on the docket. *
Hello,
I am writing today to strongly oppose the sale of Allete to the Canadian Pension Plan Investment
Board and Global Infrastructure Partners. There are many reasons that this would be a horribledecision for not only Minnesota residents but Americans in general. This decision would set aprecedence for other private equity groups across the country. Selling a public utility to a privateequity would be dangerous and crooked. Energy should not be dictated by the drive for profits butrather the desire to best serve the residents of Minnesota. The sale of Allete to these firms wouldendanger a majority of Minnesota residents served by this grid, it’s very likely that thesecorporations would pass large future costs off to residents and therefore skyrocket monthly utilities.This would also put reliability of service to Minnesota homes at risk, something that cannot happenfor a multitude of reasons. I can’t think of anything that private equity has taken over from publicmanagement and made that service cheaper, more reliable, or more accessible for the majority ofpeople. This isn’t about a simple sale, this is about principle and about protecting Minnesotans oftoday and of the future. Please do not allow this sale to go through and keep utilities public for thesake of your residents (the people you work for).

Subject: No BlackRock buyout

important
 
Hello Minnesota Public Utility Commission,
 I'm writing to ask you all to take a stand and say "no" to BlackRock's attempt to buy out utilitiesin the state of Minnesota. This is a blatant attempt at monopolizing our access to criticalutilities. The people of MN deserve manageable utility costs that are negotiated with our bestinterests in mind, and BlackRock will not have the interests of the people and the great state ofMN in mind.  Thank you,Jessica   
"In the end, we are all of one community, one Earth, and we are far stronger working together than apart."  
~ Bruce G. Marcot

Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commission,
I am writing to oppose Blackrock buying into Minnesota Power. Private Equity Firms
should not be allowed to own Public Utilities. They are not publicly traded and there isno way to know what anything they own is worth. Furthermore, they are all aboutmaximizing profits to their owners. Who even are the Owners of Blackrock? Do theyeven have shareholders? They will never serve the Public Interest or the interests ofMinnesota Power electrical customers.
Regards,Ayrlahn Johnson
2277 183rd Ave.Mora, MN 55051612-991-0568

Subject: REJECT the sale of ALLETE/Minnesota Power to BlackRock.
Date: Tuesday, August 26, 2025 9:54:51 AM
You don't often get email from kevdmiller5150@yahoo.com. Learn why this is important
Please don't ruin Minnesota 
Kevin Miller
kevdmiller5150@yahoo.com

117 South First Street • Montevideo, MN  56265  
 
 
 
CUREmn.org    320 -269 -2984  
 
 
 
August 25 , 2025        Submitted via eDockets  
 
Mike Bull  
Acting Executive Secretary  
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
121 7th Place East, Suite 350  
St. Paul, MN 55101 -2147 
  
 
Re:  In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partner s, Docket 
Nos. E-015/PA -24-198 and E -015/M -24-383 
  
Acting Executive Secretary Bull: 
 
CURE submits this letter to address a matter that was brought to our attention by another party 
to this proceeding. Last week LiUNA’s representative reached out to CURE regarding our August 
14 reply comment in this docket. We write this letter only to clarify an issue raised by LiUNA and 
do not seek to add any arguments or material facts to the docket.  
 
CURE does not believe that LiUNA witness Erin Bryant directly profits from the Partners ’ 
investment funds , based on information available to CURE.1 CURE continues to believe that 
LiUNA witness Erin Bryant has considerable expertise in her role at LiUNA.  
 
We regret this filing after the comment period has ended , and trust that the commissioners will 
weigh this information as they see fit.  
 
/s/ Hudson Kingston     
Hudson B. Kingston  
Legal Director  
P.O. Box 712  
Ely, MN 55731  
hudson@curermn.org   
 
1 CURE has reviewed LiUNA communications, portions of the record highlighted  by LiUNA, and publicly available 
information on LiUNA officer compensation.

This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.You don't often get email from shelly.lynnw89@gmail.com . Learn why this is importantFrom: Shelly Wiita < shelly.lynnw89@gmail.com > 
Sent:  Thursday, August 21, 2025 3:46 PM
To: Sieben, Katie (PUC) < katie.sieben@state.mn.us >
Subject: Potential Sale of Minnesota Power to BlackRock
Good Afternoon,
I am writing in regards to the recent interest from BlackRock private equity to purchase
Minnesota Power. As a lifelong Duluth resident (who has already been feeling the pain of pricehikes on electricity), I fear this will be detrimental to our community. Minnesota Power hasmade great strides in sustainable energy, which reflects one of the things that makes ourcommunity great. As we all know, private equity firms (especially BlackRock) prioritize profitsabove all else, likely putting sustainability on the back burner. Our community and our planetcan't afford that. Additionally, Duluth residents simply cannot afford meaningless price hikesimplemented solely to line the pockets of the already exceedingly wealthy.
 
I beseech you to please, prioritize the paying customers who require Minnesota Power servicesto run our homes and businesses, and benefit from increasingly sustainable energy. Please putethics and values over a paycheck.
 
Thank you for your time,- Shelly Wiita

From: Katherine Bergquist
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 - Proposed Acquisition of ALLETE by GIP/BlackRock and CPP Investments
Date: Wednesday, August 20, 2025 3:44:57 PM
[You don't often get email from katherine.bergquist@gmail.com. Learn why this is important at
https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification  ]
This message may be from an external email source.Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT ServicesSecurity Operations Center.
________________________________
Dear Commissioners,
I am writing as a resident and ratepayer of Minnesota Power to voice my strong and unequivocal opposition to the
proposed acquisition of ALLETE, our utility's parent company, by Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP, a BlackRocksubsidiary) and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (CPPIB).
As a captive customer with no choice in who provides my essential electricity service, I am deeply alarmed by the
risks this private equity takeover poses to my family’s financial well-being, to local control of our energy future, andto Minnesota’s clean energy goals.
My objections are based on the overwhelming evidence presented in this docket, which led Administrative Law
Judge Megan J. McKenzie to recommend you reject this deal, finding it would result in "net harm to the public
interest" . I urge you to uphold this recommendation and deny the acquisition for the following reasons:
 1. This Deal Prioritizes Shareholder Profits Over Ratepayer ProtectionThe core motivation of private equity is to extract maximum returns for its investors in a short time frame, typically
5-7 years . To pay the massive $1.5 billion premium over ALLETE's book value , GIP and CPPIB will be underimmense pressure to increase revenue. The most direct way to do this is by raising electricity rates on captivecustomers like me. Judge McKenzie's review of nonpublic evidence confirmed this, finding it "establish[es] that thepartners are planning on significant rate increases" . We simply cannot afford to have our essential utility servicebecome a vehicle for enriching Wall Street speculators.
 2. It Threatens Minnesota's Clean Energy Transition
ALLETE has claimed this deal is necessary to fund the transition to clean energy. However, this rationale is deeply
suspect. Judge McKenzie found that Minnesota Power’s capital needs for this transition "are likely overstated" .Furthermore, BlackRock's recent actions—such as leaving a major climate coalition and its history of opposingclimate-related shareholder motions at fossil fuel companies—cast serious doubt on its commitment to a genuineclean energy future . I am terrified that a private equity owner will prioritize cheap, short-term investments (likenatural gas) over the long-term investments in wind, solar, and storage that our state mandates and our planetrequires.
 3. It Erodes Local Accountability and TransparencyAs a publicly traded company, ALLETE has certain obligations to public disclosure. Taking it private would shroud
its operations in secrecy. We have already seen a "serious lack of transparency" from the buyers, who have hiddentheir plans behind "trade secret designations and redactions" . How can we, as ratepayers, trust an entity that is not
transparent with the regulators overseeing it? This deal would move control of our power from Duluth to distant
boardrooms in New York and Canada, eroding the local accountability we depend on.
 4. It Creates Pervasive Conflicts of Interest
BlackRock is a behemoth with investments across the global economy, including in fossil fuels and potentially even
in the large industrial customers that Minnesota Power serves . This creates an unacceptable risk that decisions aboutour electricity rates and grid investments could be made to benefit BlackRock's other portfolio companies, at theexpense of residential ratepayers. The concentration of power is also alarming; the deal would give the buyerscontrol of 10 out of 13 seats on ALLETE's board , effectively silencing other voices and perspectives.
 5. The "Benefits" Are Illusory and Non-Binding
The promises made by the buyers are inadequate and largely unenforceable. A one-time offer to pay off $3.5 million
in customer debt is a pittance compared to the hundreds of millions in shareholder profits . Commitments to fundcapital investments are self-serving (as they expect a return from us) and are not legally binding terms in the mergeragreement . We are being asked to bear immense, concrete risks in exchange for vague, non-binding promises.
This acquisition offers no net benefit to the people of Minnesota. It presents only a transfer of wealth from
ratepayers to shareholders and a transfer of control from Minnesota to Wall Street. The Administrative Law Judge,the Attorney General’s office, consumer advocates (CUB), environmental groups (Sierra Club, CURE), andMinnesota Power’s own largest industrial customers all stand united in opposition because the evidence of harm isso clear.
I implore you, as my representatives tasked with protecting the public interest, to **reject this heinous deal.** Do
not allow private equity greed to jeopardize our wallets, our energy security, and our state’s climate future.
Sincerely,Katherine Bergquist
5490 Bluebell AveVirginia, MN, 55792Katherine.bergquist@gmail.com(218)591-5311

Subject: Please don"t let BlackRock (Global Infrastructure Partners) take over MN Power
Date: Wednesday, August 20, 2025 6:56:18 PM
You don't often get email from kendra@hoffmanhome.com. Learn why this is important
Hi,
I'm writing to urge you to rule against a giant non-MN-based, non-environmentally-friendly company (GIP)
take over MN Power.
Minnesota has a lot to be proud of with their steps toward being climate neutral by 2040. We're one of the
better states in the country. And with the current Federal administration working hard to tear down climate
protections that are currently in place, it's vital that the few states who are pulling in the right direction
manage to hold on to their goals and autonomy.
Please please don't let Minnesota's power fall into outside hands that do not have the earth's best interest
at heart.
Thank you,- Kendra Hoffman
This message may be from an external email source.
Do not select links or open attachments unless verified. Report all suspicious emails to Minnesota IT Services Security
Operations Center.From: Meghan Kozub
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: Private Equity and Utilties
Date: Wednesday, August 20, 2025 10:16:57 AM
You don't often get email from megkozub@gmail.com. Learn why this is important
Dear Commissioners,
I am writing to strongly urge the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission to reject the proposed
acquisition of ALLETE and Minnesota Power by BlackRock and its subsidiaries. This dealrepresents a clear threat to Minnesota ratepayers, our state’s energy reliability, and our cleanenergy future.
Judge McKenzie has already recommended rejecting the transaction, citing increased risks of:
Higher customer rates
Reduced reliability of service
Weakened financial stability of Minnesota Power
Obstacles to meeting Minnesota’s clean energy goals
It would be extraordinarly foolish to ignore Judge McKenzie's warnings. Private equity firms such as BlackRock have consistently demonstrated that their primary
focus is on short-term profit extraction, not long-term community benefit. Across the nation,private equity takeovers of essential services have led to higher costs, poorer reliability, andunderinvestment in critical infrastructure. Allowing such a firm to take control of MinnesotaPower would be a grave mistake with long-lasting consequences. There have been manyrecent examples such as JoAnn's Fabrics, etc. 
This is not simply a business transaction, it is effectively a TAKEOVER of one of
Minnesota’s most vital public utilities. The people of Minnesota deserve a utility partner thatprioritizes affordability, reliability, and carbon-free energy, not one driven by Wall Streetprofit motives.
I strongly encourage the Commission to stand with Minnesotans and reject this acquisition in
order to protect customers, preserve reliable service, and keep Minnesota on track toward itsclean energy commitments.
Thank you for your consideration and for upholding your responsibility to safeguard the
public interest.Sincerely,
Meghan Kozub
A Concerned Minnesotan 
This message may be from an external email source.

Operations Center.From: Will Benson
To: Staff, CAO (PUC)
Subject: PUC Docket Number 24-198 - Public Comment - MN Power Acquisition
Date: Wednesday, August 20, 2025 12:41:13 PM
You don't often get email from willb@aquamedix.net. Learn why this is important
Dear Minnesota Public Utilities Commissioners Sieben, Sullivan, Ham, Patridge, and Tuma,
With respect to the proposed acquisition of MN Power/Allete, I am writing to express my
support of the July 15th findings of Administrative Law Judge Megan J. McKenzie.
“In considering the true risks and benefits of the Acquisition, it is critical that the Petitioner’s
agreements and private discussions do not comport with their public statements. Thenonpublic evidence reveals [GIP and CPP’s] intent to do what private equity is expected to do– pursue profit in excess of public markets through company control.”1  – Administrative Law
Judge Megan J. McKenzie 
I also am asking that you take these finding into consideration and reject the proposed
acquisition of ALLETE, Inc., parent company of Minnesota Power, by Global InfrastructurePartners (“GIP”) and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP”) – also known as thePartners – as private equity buyout it is clearly not in the public interest.
Furthermore, I would like to point out and express my disappointment that the MN DOC, and
office of AG Keith Ellision, wrote in support of the acquisition as recently as August 4th, 2025(DOCUMENT ID 20258-221732-01 ). I was shocked to find that AG Keith Ellison's askedthe commision to reject ALJ McKenzies findings, and am highly disturbed by his stark shiftfrom skepticism to full blown support of this acquisition. I question his judgement and if hetruly had the best interests of the residents of Northern Minnesota in mind when submitting hiscomment.
Respectfully submitted,
Will Benson
willb@aquamedix.net

I'm writing to express my concern over the potential sale of Minnesota Power to Global Infrastructure
Partners. 
In a time when energy prices are soaring, selling a local power company to the largest investment
firm in the world seems like a leap backwards in assuring affordable energy prices. A rate hikereduction of. 07% and a 1 year rate freeze is a paltry deal for the citizens in north Minnesota. 
As a Minnesotan, I believe we should take care of our own, and that means not selling our utility
companies to the highest bidder. If Minnesota Power doesn't wish to run the energy needs for northMinnesota, then the state should assume control of it and guarantee affordable rates.

PUC Docket No. E-015/PA-24-198 Proposed Sale of Allete/Minnesota Power
I am writing to strongly oppose the proposed sale of Allete/Minnesota Power to BlackRock’s Global
Infrastructure Partners and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board.
This transaction does not serve the public interest. Independent Administrative Law Judge Megan J.
McKenzie already found that the deal could raise customer rates, weaken grid reliability, andundermine Minnesota’s clean energy goals. While the settlement includes short-term commitmentssuch as a one-year rate freeze, these promises are temporary and do not provide lasting protectionfor customers.
Minnesota Power is a critical utility for our state. Turning over control to private equity investors
focused on maximizing returns creates significant risk for ratepayers, workers, and the transition torenewable energy. The Commission should prioritize affordability, transparency, and long-termenergy security for Minnesotans, not speculative profit for outside investors.
For these reasons, I urge the Commission to reject this proposed acquisition.Respectfully,
AnikaMinnesota

PUC Docket No. E-015/PA-24-198
Dear Commissioners,I am asking you to reject the proposed sale of Allete/Minnesota Power to BlackRock and the Canada
Pension Plan Investment Board.
Minnesota Power provides electricity that our families, schools, hospitals, and businesses depend on
every day. Control of this utility should not be handed over to private equity firms that areaccountable only to investors. Decisions about rates, reliability, and energy planning must putMinnesotans first, not shareholders outside our state.
Promises of short term rate freezes or temporary commitments are not enough. Customers need
lasting protection from higher bills, stronger guarantees for workers, and a clear plan that keepsMinnesota on track to meet its clean energy goals.
For these reasons, I urge you to protect the public interest and deny this acquisition.Sincerely,
CoreyMinnesota
